div.head: Contents

list.item: Part II BELLIGERENT RIGHTS AND PRACTICES

ref.hi: Attitude of the United States Regarding Contraband of War, Visit and Search, etc.—Measures Affecting Neutral Trade: Control of Exports, Imports, and Bunker Coal; Black List of Firms

item.ref: Consideration of the control of exports from the United States—Suggestions as to measures for preventing trade beneficial to Germany—Withdrawal by the British and French Governments of the black list of firms in the United States—Advice of the Federal Reserve Board to banks against transfers of funds to neutral countries for German interests, May 10

Discussions with British representatives during the visit of the Balfour mission—Report of the Joint Subcommittee on Export Licenses—Attitude of the United States toward the British suggestions: reciprocal undertakings desired of Great Britain—Reservation of previous American contentions regarding rights of neutral trade and objections to Allied practices

The development of an American policy of trade control—Authorization of an embargo in the “Espionage Act,” June 15, 1917—Establishment of the Exports Council, June 22—Instructions to American diplomatic and consular officers to procure information on neutral trade; arrangements for exchange of information with the Allied Governments—The President’s statement on exports control, June 26—Appeals from the Allied Governments for action in support of their policies

Proclamation of July 9, 1917, restricting exports—Statement to the European neutrals, July 24, of the American policy of exports control; request for information on their needs—Resolution of the Exports Council, approved August 17, denying licenses for exports to enemies and allies of enemies, etc.—Discussions with the British Government regarding coordination of exports control and trade agreements with neutrals—British proposal for a notice to neutral banks to refrain from transactions in enemy interests—Establishment of the Exports Administrative Board, August 21

Proclamation of August 27, 1917, further restricting exports; explanatory statements by the President and the Exports Administrative Board—Bunker license rules of August 31 and October 5—Denial of licenses for shipments through the war zone in sailing vessels—Proclamation of September 7 restricting exports of coin, bullion, and currency—Refusal of the United States to join in the proposed notice to neutral banks—Suspension by the United States and the Allies of licenses for exports to the northern European neutrals—Further discussion with the Allies regarding agreements with the neutrals

Establishment of the War Trade Board, October 12—Press statement regarding exports to neutrals—Discussions conducted through American delegates to the Inter-Allied Conference—Proclamations of November 28, further restricting exports and requiring licenses for certain imports
Publication of the enemy trading list of firms in Latin American countries, December 5—Instructions to consular officers in those countries

ref.hi: Negotiations with Denmark, Norway, and Sweden Concerning Exports and Shipping

item.ref: Representations as to the commercial situation and needs of the Scandinavian countries—The Swedish special mission to the United States—The Scandinavian conference, May 9–11—The Norwegian special mission to the United States
Memorandum of the Exports Council to the neutral representatives, July 24—Swedish attempt to organize a neutral conference—The Danish special mission to the United States
Discussions in connection with the American mission to the Inter-Allied Conference—Negotiations with the Danish and Norwegian representatives at Washington—The Scandinavian conference, November 28–30

Negotiations with Swedish representatives at London: the question of purchase of iron ore—Proposals for a temporary modus Vivendi with Sweden—Announcement of Christmas concessions to the neutrals—Further negotiations with Denmark and Norway
Negotiations with Switzerland: Silk Agreement of August 9; General Agreement of December 5

ref.hi: Negotiations with Spain: the Question of Purchases in Spain by the American Expeditionary Force
Censorship of Wireless Telegraphy, Cables, and Mails
The Taking Over of German Merchant Ships in American Ports—Their Status in Foreign Courts

ref.hi: The Maintenance of Neutrality in the Panama Canal Zone: Regulations Applying to Warships and Merchant Ships
The Treatment of Armed Merchant Ships in Neutral Ports
The Treatment of Belligerent Submarines in Neutral Ports—Suggested Internment of Crews of Refugee Merchant Ships

div.head: List of Papers
div.p: [Incoming papers are listed chronologically under date of receipt. Unless otherwise specified, the correspondence is from or to officials in the Department of State.]
PART II: BELLIGERENT RIGHTS AND PRACTICES

p.hi: Attitude of the United States Regarding Contraband of War, Visit and Search, etc.—Measures Affecting Neutral Trade: Control of Exports, Imports, and Bunker Coal; Black List of Firms

consideration of the control of exports from the united states-suggestions as to measures for preventing trade beneficial to germany–withdrawal by the british and french governments of the black list of firms in the united states—advice of the federal reserve board to banks against transfers of funds to neutral countries for german interests, may 10

row.cell: Report of the War Trade Committee
Draft bill regarding trade with the enemy.
From the Ambassador in Great Britain (tel.)
Quotes note of Apr. 7 and memorandum of Apr. 6 from the British Minister of Blockade on withdrawal of statutory black list as concerning the United States.
From the Consul General at London
Forwards copy of his letter of Apr. 3 to Page and British memorandum of Mar. 30 on effect which U. S. entry into the war might have on blockade. Comments.
From the Chargé in the Netherlands (tel.)
British inquiry regarding U. S. attitude toward citizens of enemy origin under suspicion, and adoption of blacklisting system.
Bill introduced in Congress to prohibit exports except under special license.
To the Chargé in the Netherlands (tel.)
Black-list measures must be enacted by Congress. Early understanding with Great Britain expected.
Inquires if he should cooperate with British Embassy regarding blacklisting of Spanish firms.
From the Ambassador in Great Britain (tel.)
British withdrawal of black lists as relating to the United States, Philippines, and Porto Rico.
Inquires nature of suggested cooperation in black-list measures. No policy yet adopted.
From the Ambassador in Great Britain
Transmits Balfour’s note of Apr. 10 enclosing summaries of telegrams to Spring Rice on trade and transport, for U. S. consideration.
From the Governor of the Federal Reserve Board
Forwards copy of his circular letter of May 10 to Federal Reserve Banks on desirability of preventing transfer of credits to neutral countries for account of alien enemies.
Transmits copy of French note of Apr. 30 announcing removal of U. S. and Philippine commercial houses from French black list.
Reports French activities in restricting commerce of Central powers. U. S. representation on committees is invited.
Transmits French report on blockade enforcement; measures recommended to the United States. Comments.

p.hi: discussions with british representatives during the visit of the balfour mission—report of the joint subcommittee on export licenses—attitude of the united states toward the british suggestions: reciprocal undertakings desired of great britain-reservation of previous american contentions regarding rights of neutral trade and objections to allied practices

row.cell: Memoranda on attitude of various neutral European countries toward trade with the Allies and with the enemy, and toward shipping.
From the Commercial Adviser of the British Embassy
Memoranda on control of neutral tonnage and control over the supply of bunkers.
Report of the Joint Subcommittee on Export Licenses
Restriction of trade: procedure and requisite machinery therefor. Coal policy adopted by Great Britain.
Report of the Subcommittee on Statistics and Sources of Information
Method for supplementing machinery of London committees in gathering information on rationing situation in neutral countries.
U. S. policy on questions relating to exports control.
Prospect of an after-war trade boycott causes alarm in Germany.
From the Commercial Adviser of the British Embassy
Unsettled war-trade questions, for discussion before departure of British mission.
Tentative trade arrangements between Great Britain and the United States.
Method of exercising bunker control; British draft memorandum of May 24 on this subject. (Read to Lord Percy.)

p.hi: the development of an american policy of trade control—authorization of an embargo in the “espionage act,” june 15, 1917—establishment of the exports council, june 22—instructions to american diplomatic and consular officers to procure information on neutral trade arrangements for exchange of information with the allied governments—the president’s statement on exports control, june 26—appeals from the allied governments for action in support of their policies

row.cell: From the Consul General at London (tel.)
Special licenses necessary for U. S. shipments of rubber goods via Halifax.
From the Ambassador in Great Britain (tel.)
Proposed establishment in London of a permanent U. S. technical mission for war-trade objectives.
Efforts of Inter-Ministerial Financial Commission to block financial interests of the enemy.
Instructions regarding joint meetings of Allied Ministers.
From the Consul General at London (tel.)
British suggestion of concerted policy to prevent exports to firms in Latin America assisting the enemy.
To the Ambassador in Great Britain (tel.)
Nominating representatives for committees already established, rather than sending technical mission, is being considered.
From the Commercial Adviser of the British Embassy
Suggestions regarding treatment of neutral countries under U. S. embargo legislation.
To the Consul General at London (tel.)
Inquiry regarding activity of firms in Latin America assisting the enemy
Reply to inquiry regarding shipment of automobiles, etc., to foreign countries.
French invitation to send U. S. representative to Permanent International Committee of Economic Action.
To the Minister in Sweden (tel.); mutatis mutandis, to diplomatic officers in the other neutral countries
Instructions to forward all available information on enemy trading, and to cooperate with colleagues on war matters. To be repeated to consular officers.
Information regarding certain firms suspected of using exports to advantage of the enemy.
To the Ambassador in Great Britain (tel.); mutatis mutandis, to diplomatic officers in certain other countries
Quotes Department’s circular telegram of June 20, with instructions regarding reciprocal cooperation.
Inquires meaning of instruction, “Consuls will perform conventional consular services without regard to British black list.”
To diplomatic officers in certain Latin American countries (tel.)
Instructions to give publicity to extracts from the President’s statement regarding policy of exports control. To be repeated to consuls.
British difficulties regarding curtailment of supplies to the enemy pending announcement of U. S. policy.
Expediency of measures to prevent neutrals profiting by U. S. shipments and furnishing the enemy with surmlies.
From the Ambassador in Great Britain (tel.)
Quotes instructions to British missions in neutral countries directing cooperation with U. S. colleagues in war matters.
Memorandum regarding argument of northern neutrals that restriction of supplies would throw them into the arms of Germany.
U. S. consuls will continue notarial, invoice, and like services for firms on British black list.
From the Ambassador in Great Britain
Meeting to consider proposal for extension of financial blockade. Enclosures: copy of minutes; draft of proposal for publication.
From the Consul General at London
Data regarding suspicious firms in Latin America has been sent to British special mission. Liquidation of German firms in the United States and Great Britain discussed.

div.p: proclamation of july 9, 1917, restricting exports—statement to the european neutrals, july 24, of the american policy of exports control; request for information on their needs—resolution of the exports council, approved august 17, denying licenses for exports to enemies and allies of enemies, etc.—discussions with the british government regarding coordination of exports control and trade agreements with neutrals—british proposal for a notice to neutral banks to refrain from transactions in enemy interests—establishment of the exports administrative board, august 21

row.cell: From the Consul General at Rio de Janeiro (tel.)
U. S. commercial delegate invited to sit with Commercial Committee of the Allies. Instructions requested.
From the Ambassador in Great Britain (tel.): Commercial Attaché to Exports Council
U. S. measures for control of exports unsatisfactory. Complete prohibition recommended for certain countries.
Reply to request for special permit to receive goods from firm in Sweden on British black list.
Consideration being given note on expediency of measures for controlling: exports to neutrals.
To the Consul General at Rio de Janeiro (tel.)
Instructions regarding cooperation with consular officers of Governments opposed to Germany.
The Exports Council to the Danish Legation; mutatis mutandis, to the Legations of the other northern European neutral countries
Statement of American policy of exports control and request for information on Denmark’s needs.
The United States has not issued any black list of firms.
Presents copy of Statistics of Imports into Scandinavia and the Netherlands for May.
From the Ambassador in Great Britain (tel.)
British request for reply regarding suggestions for extension of financial blockade.
France instructs its missions in neutral countries to cooperate with American missions in supplying needed information.
To the Ambassador in Great Britain (tel.)
Conversation with British representatives regarding effect of a U. S. embargo on exports to the European neutrals.
Forwards November edition of British trade agreements with neutrals, and other information on the subject.
To the Chargé in the Netherlands (tel.)
Instructions to obtain informally all possible information from British and French colleagues on matters of blockade, statistics, etc.
Summary of British negotiations with various neutral countries regarding tonnage.
To the Ambassador in Great Britain (tel.)
Certain precautionary measures taken regarding financial blockade; no further action possible until passage by Congress of Enemy Trading Act.
To the Ministers in northern European neutral countries (tel.)
Data being sought on needs of certain neutrals; further discussions with Great Britain and France on embargo policy.
To the Brazilian Embassy; mutatis mutandis, to missions of other Allied and Associated countries
Forwards copy of letter of Aug. 1 from Secretary of Commerce regarding issuance of licenses for shipments of iron, steel plates, etc.
Assurance of cooperation in restriction of exports; necessity for revision of certain agreements with neutrals.
To diplomatic officers in all countries (tel.)
Forwards resolution of Exports Council, approved Aug. 17, denying licenses for exports to enemies and allies of enemies. To be repeated to consuls.
For U. S. adherence: proposed notice to neutral banks to refrain from transactions in interest of the enemy.
Establishment of an Exports Administrative Board and an Exports Council.
From the Ambassador in Great Britain (tel.)
British suggestion of an Allied blockade council or blockade consultative body to be set up in Washington.
Measures necessary to secure identic policy between Great Britain and the United States regarding exports restriction.
British proposal of conferences at Washington and London for extending mutual information regarding trade restrictions.

p.hi: proclamation of august 27, 1917, further restricting exports explanatory statements by the president and the exports administrative board—bunker license rules of august 31 and october 5–denial of licenses for shipments through the war zone in sailing vessels—proclamation of september 7 restricting exports of coin, bullion, and currency-refusal of the united states to join in the proposed notice to neutral banks-suspension by the united states and the allies of licenses for exports to the northern european neutrals—further discussion with the allies regarding agreements with the neutrals

row.cell: To diplomatic officers in certain countries
Instructions to give publicity to the proclamation further restricting exports and to the President’s explanatory statement as quoted.
To the Secretary of the Treasury; similar letters to the Attorney General and Secretary of Commerce
Forwards British note of Aug. 18 proposing financial restrictions on neutral banks. Opinion requested.
Bureau of Export Licenses to withhold for the present licenses for controlled commodities for northern neutrals.
Supremely important to cut off the enemy’s supplies of credit.
U. S. assent to financial restrictions on neutral banks suggested by Great Britain would be unwise.
Inquires regarding U. S. cooperation with Allies in proposed financial restrictions on neutral banks.
Commercial relations with Grubnau & Son, Philadelphia, suspended by France. Inquires action to be taken.
From the Acting Secretary of the Treasury
Control of foreign exchange, etc., obtainable under existing legislation, may attain objects sought by British proposal re financial restrictions on neutral banks.
Restriction in export of coin, bullion, and currency.
Public statement of Exports Administrative Board
List of certain articles of commerce covered by proclamation of Aug. 27 restricting exports.
Inexpedient now to join in proposed notice to neutral banks.
French attitude toward Grubnau firm not understood, in view of removal of U. S. firms from black list.
Public statement of Exports Administrative Board
Refusal of export licenses to sailing vessels passing through war zone.
From the Commercial Adviser of the British Embassy
Forwards letter of Sept. 22, with enclosures, from Secretary of British Embassy to McCormick: further discussion of British trade agreements with neutrals.
From the Commercial Adviser of the British Embassy
Suspension of export licenses on commodities to Scandinavia and Holland from British Empire; exceptions.
Presents memoranda on British and French adherence to U. S. embargo policy, exceptions to be granted by way of barter.
To the Ambassador in Great Britain (tel.)
No shipments to Scandinavia; certain exceptions.
To the Ambassador in Great Britain (tel.); the same to diplomatic officers in certain other countries
Quotes Swiss press criticism of U. S. export restrictions. Danger of allowing the United States to assume full responsibility for restrictions.
Public statement of Exports Administrative Board
List of articles not requiring an export license under proclamation of Aug. 27.
Regulations for suspending export licenses for commodities which are to be carried on sailing vessels through war zone.
Public statement of Exports Administrative Board
Policy with regard to granting bunkers to neutral vessels.
Alteration made in proposed notice to neutral banks. U. S. adherence urged.
To the Ambassador in Spain (tel.); the same to diplomatic officers in certain other neutral countries
Explanation of U. S. blockade policy; French and British decisions will be independent.
Russian representations against strict embargo on Sweden.
Authorization of the Exports Administrative Board
No vessel permitted to clear U. S. 962 port without license for cargo, bunker fuel, etc.
To the Ambassador in Great Britain (tel.)
Continued consideration of treatment of northern neutrals and of possible effect of strict embargo.
Shall invoices from German and pro-German firms continue to be certified?

p.hi: establishment of the war trade board, october 12—press statement regarding exports to neutrals—discussions conducted through american delegates to the inter-allied conference—proclamations of november 28, further restricting exports and requiring licenses for certain imports

row.cell: Establishment of a War Trade Board, etc.
From the Ambassador in Great Britain (tel.)
British reasons for desiring complete embargo.
Instructions to report at The Hague as Special Assistant of Department of State; duties assigned.
Consuls will continue to certify invoices from German and pro-German firms.
Explanation of French measures regarding firm of Carl Grubnau of Philadelphia.
To the Ambassador in Great Britain (tel.); the same to diplomatic officers in certain neutral countries
For publication: U. S. policy regarding embargo on exports to neutrals.
British request of Italy to cooperate in prohibiting shipments to northern neutrals. Sweden’s new Government friendly to Allies.
From the Commercial Adviser of the British Embassy
Forwards note of Oct. 23 from the Acting Chairman of W. T. B. to Secretary of British Embassy re responsibility for tightening of blockade. And reply of Oct. 24.
From Assistant Director of Bureau of War Trade Intelligence of W. T. B.
Proposed rule governing applications for licenses for export of arms and ammunition sub-mitted for approval.
To Assistant Director of Bureau of War Trade Intelligence of W. T. B.
Proposed rule governing applications for licenses for export of arms and ammunition approved.
Approval of British cooperation in embargo on exports to northern neutrals. Enclosure: explanatory-note re France’s adhesion.
Members of firm Grubnau & Son are American citizens and trade restriction in their case seems unnecessary.
From the Commercial Adviser of the British Embassy
Forwards copy of British note to W. T. B. regarding apportionment between Allies of various rations allotted neutrals.
From the Ambassador in Great Britain (tel.)
Suggests that applications for licenses for shipments to individual American importers come through W. T. B.
From the Consul General at London
Recommends that the United States announce white lists in connection with South American trade.
To the Ambassador in Great Britain (tel.): Richards to McCormick
No arrangements yet made to take the place of British navicert system.
From the Delegate to the Inter-Allied Council (tel.): to McAdoo
Modification of British financial embargo plan thought necessary before U. S. adherence.
From the Ambassador in Great Britain (tel.): McCormick to W. T. B.
Proposes suggesting to British Blockade Ministry plan for control of exports by U. S. licenses in lieu of letters of assurance.
President Wilson to the Special Representative (tel.)
Disapproves suggested method of controlling Norway’s exports; points out only legitimate method.
To the Ambassador in Great Britain (tel.): Jones to McCormick
Explanation of the President’s telegram regarding Norwegian exports.
From the Ambassador in Great Britain (tel.)
Difficulty in moving U. S. consignments shipped from the East via Great Britain; Pacific route more desirable.
To the Ambassador in France (tel.): W. T. B. to McCormick
Authorization of plan for discontinuance of navicerts in favor of control by U. S. export licenses.
U. S. adherence to British and French declaration of policy regarding priority of food shipments to Europe is urged.
Prohibition of certain imports except under license.
Public statement of W. T. B.
Governmental control over imports into the United States.
From the Special Representative of W. T. B. (tel): to W. T. B.
Quotes Balfour as pointing out increasing export difficulties with neutral powers contiguous to Germany. Recommendations.
From the Ambassador in Great Britain (tel.): Frothingham to W. T. B.
Suggestions regarding machinery for establishing U. S. license system which will displace navicerts.
Reports resolutions of blockade and finance sections of Inter-Allied Conference to insure provisioning of invaded countries, etc.

p.hi: publication of the enemy trading list of firms in latin american countries, december 5—instructions to consular officers in those countries

row.cell: To diplomatic officers in Latin American countries (tel.)
Forwards enemy trading list of firms in Latin American countries. To be repeated to consuls.
To consular officers in Latin American countries
Instructions to report data for establishing enemy trading list and list of approved firms. Enclosure: extract from W. T. B. general instructions.
Question of excluding from commerce with the United States Norwegian firms which import goods from Germany.
To diplomatic officers in Latin American countries (tel.)
Instruct consuls to forward at once names of firms which should be eliminated from enemy trading list.
From the Commercial Adviser of the British Embassy
Measures to be used in northern neutral countries for controlling imports when embargo is raised.
Salvador guarantees future neutrality of Banco Salvadoreño and requests its removal from enemy trading list.
From the Ambassador in Great Britain (tel.): Crosby to McAdoo
Revision of plan for financial blockade submitted for approval.
To the Consul General at London (tel.)
Merchandise from the United States to war zone in Allied sailing vessels prohibited; restriction of neutral sailing vessels attempted.
Invitation for U. S. delegates to join International Committee of Economic Action.
Banco Salvadoreño removed from W. T. B. enemy trading list.
Organization, functions, and activities of the War Trade Board.

p.hi: Negotiations with Denmark, Norway, and Sweden Concerning Exports and Shipping

representations as to the commercial situation and needs of the scandinavian countries-the swedish special mission to the united states-the scandinavian conference, may 9–11—the norwegian special mission to the united states

row.cell: Contemplated embargo on northern neutrals will create feeling of resentment against the United States.
Representations regarding commercial situation and Norway’s needs.
Swedish special mission en route to the United States; effect upon Russia of restriction of Swedish imports.
Conference in Sweden of Scandinavian Ministers.
Subjects discussed and measures of cooperation agreed upon at Scandinavian conference.
Scandinavian conference agreed to continue policy of neutrality and to cooperate with neutral states for protection of joint interests; no reexportations.
Suggests modification of proposed demands upon Sweden regarding compensation for exports from the United States.
List of Swedish ships detained in U. S. ports.
Will the United States receive Nansen as Minister on Special Mission with a view to securing for Norway necessary importations?
Nansen will be received by the United States.
Postponement of Swedish wheat purchases in the United States.
Danish commercial situation; necessity for trade with both belligerent groups.
Question of exports from Scandinavia to Germany. Recommendations.
Recommends that Norway be subjected to less trade restriction than Sweden or Denmark.
Urges emphatic demand that Sweden stop enormous exports of iron ore to Germany.

p.hi: memorandum of the exports council to the neutral representatives, july 24—swedish attempt to organize a neutral conference—the danish special mission to the united states

row.cell: Swedish commercial situation; urgency of stopping Swedish exports to Germany and securing Russian transit.
Remarks of Doctor Nansen to President Wilson
Presentation of letters of credence as Minister of Norway on Special Mission.
President Wilson’s reply to Doctor Nansen
Acceptance of letters of credence as Minister of Norway on Special Mission.
Reports visit and conversation of Swedish Minister in Norway.
Swedish attempt to organize a neutral conference.
Press comment on proposed neutral conference at Stockholm.
Sweden empowers Nordvall to negotiate for U. S. foodstuffs, etc.

Possibility of Norway being involved in the war; Germany’s threatening attitude.

Dispatch to Washington of Swedish commissioner to continue negotiations for supplies and to discuss Sweden’s exports to Germany.
Transit licenses to Russia granted provided the United States will furnish equivalent quantity of goods for Swedish consumption.

Urges British permission for passage of rye to Sweden in return for wheat furnished Belgian Relief.
Necessity for clear embargo policy on part of the United States.

Quotes British reply to request to permit passage of consignment of ryc to Sweden.
Difficulties facing Denmark as result of U. S. embargo; more satisfactory arrangement urged.
Believed impossible to compel Sweden to discontinue ore exports to Germany. Curtailment thought possible.
Negotiations regarding embargo on exports to Scandinavian countries.

Instructions to make representations regarding British refusal to permit passage of rye to Sweden.
Requests that Danish commercial representatives be received by Exports Council, Shipping Board, etc.
Future policy will be to refuse Norway supplies while it continues exports benefiting the enemy.
New Swedish Administration may be favorable to Allies. Delay and leniency in trade negotiations advisable.
No shipments to Denmark pending negotiations. Understanding to be reached soon.
Danger of Denmark being forced to compensate Germany in order to secure fuel oil for lights and water.

British authorization for passage of consignment of rye to Sweden.
Interview with Foreign Minister on reduction of exports to Germany.
Advises noncommittal attitude while negotiations between W. T. B. and Norwegian commission are proceeding.

Forwards substance of British telegrams offering further suggestions regarding trade agreement with Denmark.

Danish trade negotiations with W. T. B.: limit of exports to Central powers.

Recommendations regarding settlement of trade negotiations with northern neutrals and Switzerland.

The President’s instructions regarding trade agreements with Norway and Denmark.
